data.value: Find peaks inside a signal based on peak properties.

This function takes a 1-D array and finds all local maxima by simple comparison of neighboring values. Optionally, a subset of these peaks can be selected by specifying conditions for a peak's properties.
A signal with peaks.

data.type_: number or ndarray or sequence, optional

data.value: Required height of peaks. Either a number,
, an array matching
or a 2-element sequence of the former. The first element is always interpreted as the  minimal and the second, if supplied, as the maximal required height.

data.type_: number or ndarray or sequence, optional

data.value: Required threshold of peaks, the vertical distance to its neighboring samples. Either a number,
, an array matching
or a 2-element sequence of the former. The first element is always interpreted as the  minimal and the second, if supplied, as the maximal required threshold.
Required minimal horizontal distance (>= 1) in samples between neighbouring peaks. Smaller peaks are removed first until the condition is fulfilled for all remaining peaks.

data.type_: number or ndarray or sequence, optional

data.value: Required prominence of peaks. Either a number,
, an array matching
or a 2-element sequence of the former. The first element is always interpreted as the  minimal and the second, if supplied, as the maximal required prominence.

data.type_: number or ndarray or sequence, optional

data.value: Required width of peaks in samples. Either a number,
, an array matching
or a 2-element sequence of the former. The first element is always interpreted as the  minimal and the second, if supplied, as the maximal required width.

Raised if a peak's properties have unexpected values (see
and

In the context of this function, a peak or local maximum is defined as any sample whose two direct neighbours have a smaller amplitude. For flat peaks (more than one sample of equal amplitude wide) the index of the middle sample is returned (rounded down in case the number of samples is even). For noisy signals the peak locations can be off because the noise might change the position of local maxima. In those cases consider smoothing the signal before searching for peaks or use other peak finding and fitting methods (like

This function may return unexpected results for data containing NaNs. To avoid this, NaNs should either be removed or replaced.
To demonstrate this function's usage we use a signal
supplied with SciPy (see
). Let's find all peaks (local maxima) in
whose amplitude lies above 0.
fig-scipy.signal._peak_finding.find_peaks-1.png
We can select peaks below 0 with
or use arrays matching
in size to reflect a changing condition for different parts of the signal.
fig-scipy.signal._peak_finding.find_peaks-2.png
Another useful condition for periodic signals can be given with the
argument. In this case, we can easily select the positions of QRS complexes within the electrocardiogram (ECG) by demanding a distance of at least 150 samples.
fig-scipy.signal._peak_finding.find_peaks-3.png
Especially for noisy signals peaks can be easily grouped by their prominence (see
). E.g., we can select all peaks except for the mentioned QRS complexes by limiting the allowed prominence to 0.6.
fig-scipy.signal._peak_finding.find_peaks-4.png

And, finally, let's examine a different section of the ECG which contains beat forms of different shape. To select only the atypical heart beats, we combine two conditions: a minimal prominence of 1 and width of at least 20 samples.
fig-scipy.signal._peak_finding.find_peaks-5.png
